elements.content: The development of new chemiresistive materials for use in chemical sensors that operate near ambient conditions could potentially reduce the costs of implementation, encouraging their use in new areas. Conductive metal–organic frameworks represent one intriguing class of materials for further investigation in this area, given their vast structural diversity and the specificity of adsorbate interactions afforded by their crystallinity. Here, we re-examine the electronic conductivity of the desolvated and acetonitrile-solvated microporous framework Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] (pdt2– = 2,3-pyrazinedithiolate), and find that the conductivity in the pristine material is 200-fold greater than in the solvated state, highlighting the sensitivity of sample conductivity to guest inclusion. Additionally, the desolvated material is demonstrated to selectively adsorb the gaseous hydrocarbons ethane, ethylene, acetylene, propane, propylene, and cis-2-butene at ambient temperature. Investigation of the effect of gas adsorption on conductivity using an in situ measurement cell reveals a chemiresistive response for each adsorbate, and the change in conductivity with adsorbate pressure closely follows an empirical model identical in form to the Langmuir–Freundlich equation. The relative sensitivity of the framework to each adsorbate is, surprisingly, not correlated with binding strength. Instead, the differences in chemiresistive response between adsorbates are found to correlate strongly with gas phase specific heat capacity of the adsorbate. Nanoconfinement effects, manifesting as a relative deviation from the expected chemiresistive response, may influence charge transport in the case of the largest adsorbate considered, cis-2-butene. Time-resolved conductance and adsorption measurements additionally show that the chemiresistive response of the sensor equilibrates on a shorter time scale than gas adsorption, suggesting that interparticle contacts limit conduction through the bulk material and that conductivity at the crystallite surfaces is most responsive to gas adsorption.

elements.content: The quantification of gas mixture composition is a critical capability for any industry that requires atmospheric control or employs reactive gases, including the chemical refinement, semiconductor, and medical industries. Gas sensors are typically constructed from three basic components: a sensing material that undergoes a change in physical properties upon interaction with analyte, a complementary transducer, and the electronics required to measure the electrical response of the transducer. Sensors based on chemiresistivitya change in electrical conductance upon interaction with a target compoundare particularly attractive, as they eliminate the need for an expensive transducer, such as a piezoelectric sensor, photometer, or spectrometer. However, suitable chemiresistive materials do not exist for many environments and gas compositions. The development of new chemiresistive gas sensors may therefore enhance control over existing processes and environments and promote greater adoption of sensors in industry, as a result of anticipated cost reductions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The quantification of gas mixture composition is a critical capability for any industry that requires atmospheric control or employs reactive gases, including the chemical refinement, semiconductor, and medical industries. Gas sensors are typically constructed from three basic components: a sensing material that undergoes a change in physical properties upon interaction with analyte, a complementary transducer, and the electronics required to measure the electrical response of the transducer. Sensors based on chemiresistivitya change in electrical conductance upon interaction with a target compoundare particularly attractive, as they eliminate the need for an expensive transducer, such as a piezoelectric sensor, photometer, or spectrometer. However, suitable chemiresistive materials do not exist for many environments and gas compositions. The development of new chemiresistive gas sensors may therefore enhance control over existing processes and environments and promote greater adoption of sensors in industry, as a result of anticipated cost reductions.

elements.content: Some of the most versatile chemiresistive materials are composites of semiconducting metal oxides (e.g., TiO2 and SnO2). Sensor technologies based on such materials have been used in many applications, including hydrogen–carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon-based gas mixtures. However, they remain fundamentally limited by the high operating temperatures required, low analyte selectivity in certain instances, and a lack of rational design methodologies for tailoring sensor materials to specific gas mixtures and operating conditions.

elements.content: One possible materials solution to the challenge of designing improved chemiresistive sensors would be to replace the metal oxide sensor component with a metal–organic frameworka porous, crystalline solid composed of metal nodes connected via organic linkers. The vast structural diversity and modular constitution of metal–organic frameworks are distinct advantages compared to metal oxides, and are properties largely responsible for the widespread interest in these materials for other applications, including gas storage and catalysis. For example, the hybrid nature of metal–organic frameworks may support the amalgamation of disparate properties that rarely coexistsuch as crystallinity, microporosity, and conductivityto yield new materials with synergistic properties. Recent advances in the chemistry of electronically conductive metal–organic frameworks have introduced the prospect of coupling charge transport and selective host guest interactions. Fundamentally, highly porous materials with crystallographically defined surfaces may also provide a unique testing ground for exploring how surface–adsorbate interactions modulate electronic transportgiven that these surface interactions are expressed as changes in the bulk chemical structure. Further developing synthetic control over charge mobility in porous crystals may also promote the use of such materials in new technologies surrounding energy storage, electrocatalysis, and electronic devices.

elements.content: Previous efforts toward the synthesis and integration of metal–organic frameworks into sensor devices have been recently reviewed. Notably, there have been a number of breakthroughs with regard to chemiresistive applications of metal–organic frameworks in the presence of either redox active gases or adsorbed solvents and volatile organic guest species. For example, a chemiresistive sensor array constructed from two-dimensional triphenylene-based Cu2+ and Ni2+ frameworks has been shown to be capable of classifying a diverse range of volatile organic compounds by chemical functional group. In this case, the effect of guest binding on conductivity was found to be rather complex and somewhat unpredictable, opening up an enticing opportunity to explore the effects of adsorption on conductivity in greater detail.
elements.clean_text: Previous efforts toward the synthesis and integration of metal-organic frameworks into sensor devices have been recently reviewed. Notably, there have been a number of breakthroughs with regard to chemiresistive applications of metal-organic frameworks in the presence of either redox active gases or adsorbed solvents and volatile organic guest species. For example, a chemiresistive sensor array constructed from two-dimensional triphenylene-based Cu2+ and Ni2+ frameworks has been shown to be capable of classifying a diverse range of volatile organic compounds by chemical functional group. In this case, the effect of guest binding on conductivity was found to be rather complex and somewhat unpredictable, opening up an enticing opportunity to explore the effects of adsorption on conductivity in greater detail.

elements.content: Motivated by this study, we chose to investigate the previously reported three-dimensional conductive framework Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] (pdt2– = pyrazine-2,3-dithiolate; ) as a case study for chemiresistivity in metal–organic frameworks. This particular phase was an early example of a permanently porous, conductive metal–organic frameworkin contrast to the isostructural compound Cu­[Cu­(pdt)2]and remains a rare case of a metal–organic framework exhibiting both a measurable room-temperature conductivity (10–8 S/cm) and permanent porosity. Herein, we examine the electrical conductance of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] as a function of absolute pressure in the presence of selected light hydrocarbons. Changes in the conductance of the material in response to pure component adsorption can be directly correlated to gas adsorption measurements collected on the same equipment under identical conditions. Accordingly, it is possible to determine accurate conductivity–composition profiles in order to elucidate how specific adsorbates modulate conductivity.

This particular phase was an early example of a permanently porous, conductive metal-organic frameworkin contrast to the isostructural compound Cu[Cu(pdt)2]and remains a rare case of a metal-organic framework exhibiting both a measurable room-temperature conductivity (10-8 S/cm) and permanent porosity. Changes in the conductance of the material in response to pure component adsorption can be directly correlated to gas adsorption measurements collected on the same equipment under identical conditions. Accordingly, it is possible to determine accurate conductivity-composition profiles in order to elucidate how specific adsorbates modulate conductivity.

elements.content: The synthesis of Na2[Ni­(pdt)2] was carried out according to the literature procedure. Diffraction data were collected using a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer with the generator set at 40 kV and 40 mA, and samples were loaded onto zero-background sample holders. Elemental analyses were obtained from the Microanalytical Laboratory at the University of California, Berkeley.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

General Procedures and Measurements

The synthesis of Na2[Ni(pdt)2] was carried out according to the literature procedure. Diffraction data were collected using a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer with the generator set at 40 kV and 40 mA, and samples were loaded onto zero-background sample holders. Elemental analyses were obtained from the Microanalytical Laboratory at the University of California, Berkeley.

elements.content: The synthesis of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was adapted from a previous report. A flask was charged with 270 mL of acetonitrile and sparged with dry N2 for 30 min. Next, Na2[Ni­(pdt)2] (0.630 g, 1.62 mmol) was added to the solvent and the solution was stirred. A separate flask was charged with 75 mL of acetonitrile, sparged with dry N2 for 30 min, and CuI (0.309 g, 1.62 mmol) was added. While under a positive atmosphere of N2, the CuI solution was slowly added to the solution of Na2[Ni­(pdt)2] via a syringe, which resulted in the rapid precipitation of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] as a black solid. The solid was filtered on 0.22-μm nylon filter paper in air and activated overnight at 90 °C under high vacuum on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument equipped with a turbo pump, yielding 0.453 g (69%) of the product as a dark red microcrystalline solid. The X-ray powder diffraction pattern for the activated material is shown in Figure S1, and the gas adsorption isotherm used to calculate the Langmuir surface area is provided in Figure S2. Elemental Analysis for Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]: calculated, C 23.63%, H 0.99%, N 13.78%, S 31.54%; found, C 22.92%, H 1.05%, N 13.74%, S 30.43%.

Modified Synthesis of Cu[Ni(pdt)2]

Next, Na2[Ni(pdt)2] (0.630 g, 1.62 mmol) was added to the solvent and the solution was stirred. A separate flask was charged with 75 mL of acetonitrile, sparged with dry N2 for 30 min, and CuI (0.309 g, 1.62 mmol) was added. While under a positive atmosphere of N2, the CuI solution was slowly added to the solution of Na2[Ni(pdt)2] via a syringe, which resulted in the rapid precipitation of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] as a black solid. The solid was filtered on 0.22-μm nylon filter paper in air and activated overnight at 90 °C under high vacuum on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument equipped with a turbo pump, yielding 0.453 g (69%) of the product as a dark red microcrystalline solid. The X-ray powder diffraction pattern for the activated material is shown in Figure S1, and the gas adsorption isotherm used to calculate the Langmuir surface area is provided in Figure S2. elements.content: Gas adsorption data were measured between 0 and 1.1 bar using a Micromeritics 3-Flex instrument. Samples of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] powder were loaded into a preweighed tube, and heated at 90 °C overnight. The mass of the activated sample was used as the basis for the adsorption measurements. After an adsorption isotherm was measured, the sample was reactivated at 90 °C before measuring a subsequent adsorption isotherm.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Measurements

Gas adsorption data were measured between 0 and 1.1 bar using a Micromeritics 3-Flex instrument. Samples of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] powder were loaded into a preweighed tube, and heated at 90 °C overnight. The mass of the activated sample was used as the basis for the adsorption measurements. After an adsorption isotherm was measured, the sample was reactivated at 90 °C before measuring a subsequent adsorption isotherm.

elements.content: In an Ar-filled glovebox, activated Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was pressed into a pellet inside a 2-contact PEEK screw cell, as previously reported. The ac conductivity of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was determined using a Bio-Logic VMP-3 multipotentiostat equipped with an impedance analyzer operating between the frequencies 1 MHz and 0.01 Hz at a sinus amplitude of 100 mV and dc bias voltage of 0 mV (Figure S3). The observed spectrum was ohmic with dc bias voltage (Figure S4), linear with sinus amplitude (Figure S5), time invariant (Figure S5), and matched closely to what would be expected for a single Debye-type relaxation process with a single time constant (Figures S3, S6–S8).
elements.clean_text:
Ac Impedance Measurements

In an Ar-filled glovebox, activated Cu[Ni(pdt)2] was pressed into a pellet inside a 2-contact PEEK screw cell, as previously reported. The ac conductivity of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] was determined using a Bio-Logic VMP-3 multipotentiostat equipped with an impedance analyzer operating between the frequencies 1 MHz and 0.01 Hz at a sinus amplitude of 100 mV and dc bias voltage of 0 mV (Figure S3). The observed spectrum was ohmic with dc bias voltage (Figure S4), linear with sinus amplitude (Figure S5), time invariant (Figure S5), and matched closely to what would be expected for a single Debye-type relaxation process with a single time constant (Figures S3, S6-S8).

elements.content: Conductivity and gas adsorption data were measured simultaneously as a function of time using a custom-built conductivity cell (). Printed circuit board arrays were designed using the free computer-aided design software package PCB123 and submitted to the rapid prototyping service Sunstone Circuits for fabrication. The arrays consisted of sets of two via and two 1-oz copper rails separated by a 0.152-μm gap printed onto an FR-4 base. A segment of 1/2-in. stainless steel tubing was cut, deburred, and fitted with Swagelok ferrules. Individual boards were cut to fit within the 1/2-in. tubing, and silver coated copper wires were soldered into place. The board was then threaded through the precut tubing, and the bottom two-thirds of the tube was filled with a solventless high-vacuum epoxy (TorrSeal or Hysol 1C) such that the board was fully exposed above the end of the tube (). The gastight connection to the Micromeritics 3-Flex instrument consisted of a 1/2-in. union, a reducing union, and a two-way Swagelok ball valve for air-free sample transfers.
elements.clean_text:
Time Resolved Conductivity Measurements upon Gas Adsorption

Conductivity and gas adsorption data were measured simultaneously as a function of time using a custom-built conductivity cell (). Printed circuit board arrays were designed using the free computer-aided design software package PCB123 and submitted to the rapid prototyping service Sunstone Circuits for fabrication. The arrays consisted of sets of two via and two 1-oz copper rails separated by a 0.152-μm gap printed onto an FR-4 base. A segment of 1/2-in. stainless steel tubing was cut, deburred, and fitted with Swagelok ferrules. Individual boards were cut to fit within the 1/2-in. tubing, and silver coated copper wires were soldered into place. The board was then threaded through the precut tubing, and the bottom two-thirds of the tube was filled with a solventless high-vacuum epoxy (TorrSeal or Hysol 1C) such that the board was fully exposed above the end of the tube (). The gastight connection to the Micromeritics 3-Flex instrument consisted of a 1/2-in. union, a reducing union, and a two-way Swagelok ball valve for air-free sample transfers.

elements.content: Schematic of the conductivity cell used for in situ conductance measurements on a gas adsorption analyzer. A pressed pellet of the polycrystalline Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] sample was embedded between two copper rails represented by yellow strips, which sit on top of the green circuit board; the resistance of the completed circuit is then measured.

elements.content: The circuit board and adapter were transferred to an Ar-filled glovebox, and a thin pellet (∼50 μm) of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] powder was formed between the two copper rails using a mechanical press. The circuit board was sealed in the measurement cell in the Ar-filled glovebox, and the entire apparatus was then connected to the analysis port on the gas sorption analyzer. After multiple cycles between 1 bar and <1 μbar of helium, the cell was left to stabilize under vacuum. In a typical measurement, currents of 1–10 μA were applied (depending of the resistance of the sample) and the voltage response measured with 0.5 s time resolution. An exemplary time dependent data set is given in Figure S9, showing clearly resolved steps between pressure points. The standard deviation of the baseline noise was ∼0.7 mV. Signal to noise ratios were ∼3:1 for the first pressure point in Figure S10 and greater than 10:1 for all subsequent pressure points. Rate of adsorption data were collected from the 3-Flex gas adsorption analyzer, using the PuTTY client to access the data transmitted from the instrument to the computer with 0.5 s time resolution.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction data for Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] were collected on Beamline 17-BM-B at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory. Approximately 3 mg of fully desolvated framework was loaded into a 1.0 mm borosilicate capillary inside a N2-filled glovebox. Each capillary was then attached to a custom designed gas-dosing cell equipped with a gas valve and transferred to the goniometer head. All adsorbed N2 was then removed by evacuating in situ using a turbomolecular pump. An Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream 800 was used to hold the temperature of the sample at 25 °C. Scattered intensity was measured by a PerkinElmer a-Si flat panel detector.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determinations

Powder X-ray diffraction data for Cu[Ni(pdt)2] were collected on Beamline 17-BM-B at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory. Approximately 3 mg of fully desolvated framework was loaded into a 1.0 mm borosilicate capillary inside a N2-filled glovebox. Each capillary was then attached to a custom designed gas-dosing cell equipped with a gas valve and transferred to the goniometer head. All adsorbed N2 was then removed by evacuating in situ using a turbomolecular pump. An Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream 800 was used to hold the temperature of the sample at 25 °C. Scattered intensity was measured by a PerkinElmer a-Si flat panel detector.

elements.content: Diffraction data were collected for the evacuated material, after which variable pressures of C2H2 and C2H4 gas were dosed using a custom-built gas dosing manifold. Each dose of gas was equilibrated on the sample for over half an hour, until no further change was observed in both the pressure above the sample and in the resulting diffraction patterns. The average wavelength of measurement was 0.45212 Å. In between dosing C2H2 and dosing C2H4, the sample was activated at 120 °C under vacuum for 1 h to remove all traces of the previously dosed gas from the material. The re-evacuated sample had a diffraction pattern that was identical to the initial evacuated sample. An extended description of the structure refinement can be found in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The parallel version of the CRYSTAL17 suite of programs was used for all calculations. The structure of activated Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2], as well as the material containing either two C2H2 or C2H4 molecules per unit cell was optimized while keeping the lattice parameters fixed at their experimental values. This prevented the unit cell from becoming too compressed due to the overestimation of dispersive interactions. Frequency calculations were carried out at the optimized geometries to confirm that they were local minima. The original tetragonal symmetry was removed in order to define the spin on each metal center in the unit cell.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Methods

The parallel version of the CRYSTAL17 suite of programs was used for all calculations. The structure of activated Cu[Ni(pdt)2], as well as the material containing either two C2H2 or C2H4 molecules per unit cell was optimized while keeping the lattice parameters fixed at their experimental values. This prevented the unit cell from becoming too compressed due to the overestimation of dispersive interactions. Frequency calculations were carried out at the optimized geometries to confirm that they were local minima. The original tetragonal symmetry was removed in order to define the spin on each metal center in the unit cell.

elements.content: The unrestricted PBE0 −D3­(BJ) hybrid density functional was employed, with the pob_TZVP basis-set, which consists of a Gaussian-type, all-electron triple-ζ basis set derived from the popular def2-TZVP, the former being devised especially for solid-state calculations. Grimme’s −D3 a posteriori correction scheme for dispersive interactions was coupled with the Becke–Johnson’s (BJ) damping function.

Grimme's -D3 a posteriori correction scheme for dispersive interactions was coupled with the Becke-Johnson's (BJ) damping function.

elements.content: A very fine DFT grid (keyword XXLGRID) was utilized, whereas on the basis of total energy convergence, a Pack–Monkhorst grid of 112 k-points (keyword SHRINK 6 6) within the first Brillouin zone was chosen. The tolerance thresholds on bielectronic Coulomb and exchange integrals (see keyword TOLINTEG), were set to 10–12 10–12 10–12 10–14 10–22. The DIIS acceleration algorithm was used throughout. Starting guesses of the density matrix for different spin multiplets were originated by assigning the spin to each metal center with the keyword ATOMSPIN, at cycle 0 of the self-consistent procedure (SCF). No locking of unpaired electronsthat is, no locking to a particular spin configuration guesswas imposed in the successive cycles of the SCF.

Starting guesses of the density matrix for different spin multiplets were originated by assigning the spin to each metal center with the keyword ATOMSPIN, at cycle 0 of the self-consistent procedure (SCF). No locking of unpaired electronsthat is, no locking to a particular spin configuration guesswas imposed in the successive cycles of the SCF.

elements.content: The synthesis of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was performed via a slight modification of the previously reported procedure to afford a dark red crystalline powder with a nearly identical Langmuir surface area of 426 m2/g. The structure of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] () has been previously reported and consists of sulfur-coordinated square planar nickel­(II) pyrazine-2,3-dithiolate units linked by nitrogen-coordinated square planar copper­(II) centers in a three-dimensional lattice. The resulting framework features square channels with edge dimensions defined by the Cu···Cu separation of 6.8132(10) Å and walls that are lined by the [Ni­(pdt)2]2– complexes. While the structure is anisotropic, significant conductivity along any of the three crystallographic axes may be expected, in view of the similarity in metal coordination environments and connectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The synthesis of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] was performed via a slight modification of the previously reported procedure to afford a dark red crystalline powder with a nearly identical Langmuir surface area of 426 m2/g. The structure of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] () has been previously reported and consists of sulfur-coordinated square planar nickel(II) pyrazine-2,3-dithiolate units linked by nitrogen-coordinated square planar copper(II) centers in a three-dimensional lattice. The resulting framework features square channels with edge dimensions defined by the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation of 6.8132(10) Å and walls that are lined by the [Ni(pdt)2]2- complexes. While the structure is anisotropic, significant conductivity along any of the three crystallographic axes may be expected, in view of the similarity in metal coordination environments and connectivity.

elements.content: Two-contact, pressed pellet conductivity measurements carried out on guest-free Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] revealed a conductivity of 2.6 μS/cm, which notably is 260 times greater than the previously reported value. This difference is likely the result of improved sample purity, homogeneity, and/or desolvation conditions. We note that measured differences in conductivity of this magnitude are not unusual, even with relatively small differences in synthetic conditions. As Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was originally reported to exhibit thermally activated conductivity, we employed ac impedance spectroscopy to distinguish between bipolar- and hopping-type conduction mechanisms, which both display exponential temperature dependences that are identical in form. By this method, a single ohmic Debye-type relaxation mode was observed for Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2], with a single time constant (Figure S3). Thus, bulk conductivity in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] possibly manifests as nearest neighbor charge hopping via small polarons localized on individual [Ni­(pdt)2]2– units, although the exact identity of the charge carriers could not be reliably determined experimentally or theoretically. Given that the observed conductivity is much higher than would be expected for a closed shell [Ni­(pdt)2]2– configuration, one possibility is that a small fraction of the [Ni­(pdt)2]2– units undergo transient oxidation along with concomitant reduction of neighboring Cu2+ ions to Cu+. However, it is also possible that the presence of small quantities of oxidized [Ni­(pdt)2]2–undetectable by our analytical methodsare responsible for the observed conductivity. This hypothesis is aligned with previous photocurrent experiments suggesting a p-type conduction mechanism.
elements.clean_text:
Hopping Charge Transport in Cu[Ni(pdt)2]

Two-contact, pressed pellet conductivity measurements carried out on guest-free Cu[Ni(pdt)2] revealed a conductivity of 2.6 μS/cm, which notably is 260 times greater than the previously reported value. This difference is likely the result of improved sample purity, homogeneity, and/or desolvation conditions. We note that measured differences in conductivity of this magnitude are not unusual, even with relatively small differences in synthetic conditions. As Cu[Ni(pdt)2] was originally reported to exhibit thermally activated conductivity, we employed ac impedance spectroscopy to distinguish between bipolar- and hopping-type conduction mechanisms, which both display exponential temperature dependences that are identical in form. By this method, a single ohmic Debye-type relaxation mode was observed for Cu[Ni(pdt)2], with a single time constant (Figure S3). Thus, bulk conductivity in Cu[Ni(pdt)2] possibly manifests as nearest neighbor charge hopping via small polarons localized on individual [Ni(pdt)2]2- units, although the exact identity of the charge carriers could not be reliably determined experimentally or theoretically. Given that the observed conductivity is much higher than would be expected for a closed shell [Ni(pdt)2]2- configuration, one possibility is that a small fraction of the [Ni(pdt)2]2- units undergo transient oxidation along with concomitant reduction of neighboring Cu2+ ions to Cu+. However, it is also possible that the presence of small quantities of oxidized [Ni(pdt)2]2-undetectable by our analytical methodsare responsible for the observed conductivity. This hypothesis is aligned with previous photocurrent experiments suggesting a p-type conduction mechanism.

elements.content: Initially, in order to examine the effect of guest adsorption on conductivity, Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was exposed to a saturated atmosphere of acetonitrile (the synthesis solvent) vapor at room temperature for 12 h. Remarkably, following this exposure, the conductivity of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]·xCH3CN decreased to 0.015 μS/cm. This value agrees well with the originally reported conductivity for Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] of 0.01 μS/cm, and is nearly 200 times lower than the conductivity measured for the desolvated framework here. Reported changes in metal–organic framework conductivity upon exposure to volatile organic compounds are typically much smalleron the order of ten percentalthough hydration of a conductive mixed-valence ruthenium metal–organic framework has also been reported to result in changes in conductivity of several orders of magnitude. The rather high sensitivity of the Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] conductivity to a volatile organic compound encouraged us to examine the effect of other compounds that typically interact less strongly with porous materialssuch as light hydrocarbonsand are therefore typically more difficult to detect and distinguish.

elements.content: For this purpose, we constructed a conductivity cell that could be attached to a Micromeritics 3-Flex gas adsorption analyzer (see for a simplified diagram). While this setup can support a number of measurement geometries, given the relatively low conductivity of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2], a two-contact method was determined to be sufficient. A thin pellet of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] (50–100 μm thick) was pressed between the two copper traces (spaced 152 μm apart) on a printed circuit board. The measurement cell was then sealed in an airtight Swagelok tube and attached to a gas adsorption analyzer.

elements.content: Using this apparatus, the room-temperature conductivity of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was initially measured in the presence of a variety of gases at 1 bar. The adsorption of nitrogen, helium, argon, or methane resulted in very small conductivity changes (∼1% or less). Given this small chemiresistive response, especially when compared to the saturated acetonitrile phase, the signal-to-noise level was too low to obtain accurate data for these gases. However, considering that Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] binds these gases only weakly and adsorbs only a small amount at room temperature, such a small change in conductivity is not unexpected.

elements.content: The Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] framework does adsorb significant quantities of hydrocarbons larger than methane, specifically ethane, propane, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, and cis-2-butene. It should be noted that the gas adsorption and separation properties of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] in the presence of carbon dioxide, methane, acetylene, and ethylene have been recently reported. Relatedly, discrete nickel­(II) dithiolene complexes have been shown to interact strongly through chemisorption with unsaturated hydrocarbons in solution. However, because the dithiolene units in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] remain unoxidized, it is unlikely that a similar mechanism is operative here. The material displays the highest adsorption capacity for acetylene followed by ethylene and also displays the strongest affinity for these gases at low pressures, as indicated by the steep rise in their adsorption isotherms up to 0.1 bar (a). In contrast, the larger olefins and paraffins all display qualitatively similar adsorption profiles, weaker binding, and adsorption that saturates at approximately one molecule for every two formula units of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]. In the case of cis-2-butene, a slight deviation from Type I adsorption behavior occurs at high pressures, in the form of a slight upturn in the adsorption curve, and could possibly be ascribed to secondary adsorption occurring outside of the pores of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]. Each adsorption isotherm was modeled using the Langmuir–Freundlich equation, and in the case of ethane, ethylene, propane, and propylene this model yielded fits in good agreement with the experimental data. For acetylene and cis-2-butene, the adsorption isotherms were better fit with a dual site Langmuir–Freundlich equation (Table S1). With this set of probe molecules displaying a range of apparent binding strengths, we sought to investigate any corresponding differences in the structure of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] upon gas loading.
elements.clean_text:
Selective Hydrocarbon Adsorption in Cu[Ni(pdt)2]

The Cu[Ni(pdt)2] framework does adsorb significant quantities of hydrocarbons larger than methane, specifically ethane, propane, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, and cis-2-butene. It should be noted that the gas adsorption and separation properties of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] in the presence of carbon dioxide, methane, acetylene, and ethylene have been recently reported. Relatedly, discrete nickel(II) dithiolene complexes have been shown to interact strongly through chemisorption with unsaturated hydrocarbons in solution. However, because the dithiolene units in Cu[Ni(pdt)2] remain unoxidized, it is unlikely that a similar mechanism is operative here. The material displays the highest adsorption capacity for acetylene followed by ethylene and also displays the strongest affinity for these gases at low pressures, as indicated by the steep rise in their adsorption isotherms up to 0.1 bar (a). In contrast, the larger olefins and paraffins all display qualitatively similar adsorption profiles, weaker binding, and adsorption that saturates at approximately one molecule for every two formula units of Cu[Ni(pdt)2]. In the case of cis-2-butene, a slight deviation from Type I adsorption behavior occurs at high pressures, in the form of a slight upturn in the adsorption curve, and could possibly be ascribed to secondary adsorption occurring outside of the pores of Cu[Ni(pdt)2]. Each adsorption isotherm was modeled using the Langmuir-Freundlich equation, and in the case of ethane, ethylene, propane, and propylene this model yielded fits in good agreement with the experimental data. For acetylene and cis-2-butene, the adsorption isotherms were better fit with a dual site Langmuir-Freundlich equation (Table S1). With this set of probe molecules displaying a range of apparent binding strengths, we sought to investigate any corresponding differences in the structure of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] upon gas loading.

Conductivity–composition profiles in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]·nC x H y (c). Colored circles indicate the estimated linear regime used to determine the sensitivity, S. Empirical fits to the data in (a–c) are shown as lines. The units for quantity adsorbed are moles of adsorbate per mole of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2].

elements.content: Adsorption of the smallest two gases, acetylene and ethylene, was structurally characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (). Upon incremental dosing from 20 to 1077 mbar of acetylene at 25 °C, the powder diffraction pattern remained consistent with the space group of the degassed crystal, while significant changes in peak intensities were observed, suggestive of gas adsorption and crystallographically structured guest binding (Figures S11–S16 and Table S3). In comparison to the degassed structure (redetermined by X-ray diffraction here), at 291 mbar of acetylene, the Fourier difference map revealed a significant increase in electron density along the center of the pore axis (see the Supporting Information for details). The inclusion of acetylene within the lattice was modeled as two carbon atoms constrained to a distance of 1.20 Å to yield the structure depicted in a. The refined structure reveals acetylene to sit 3.4117(4) Å from the centroids of the four pyrazine rings on each side of the square channel. We note that very similar adsorption sites were recently crystallographically determined for acetylene in Cu­[Cu­(pdt)2].
elements.clean_text:
Determination of Guest-Adsorbed Structures

Adsorption of the smallest two gases, acetylene and ethylene, was structurally characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (). Upon incremental dosing from 20 to 1077 mbar of acetylene at 25 °C, the powder diffraction pattern remained consistent with the space group of the degassed crystal, while significant changes in peak intensities were observed, suggestive of gas adsorption and crystallographically structured guest binding (Figures S11-S16 and Table S3). In comparison to the degassed structure (redetermined by X-ray diffraction here), at 291 mbar of acetylene, the Fourier difference map revealed a significant increase in electron density along the center of the pore axis (see the Supporting Information for details). The inclusion of acetylene within the lattice was modeled as two carbon atoms constrained to a distance of 1.20 Å to yield the structure depicted in a. The refined structure reveals acetylene to sit 3.4117(4) Å from the centroids of the four pyrazine rings on each side of the square channel. We note that very similar adsorption sites were recently crystallographically determined for acetylene in Cu[Cu(pdt)2].

elements.content: Crystal structures of acetylene (291 mbar) and ethylene (273 mbar) adsorbed in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2], as determined using powder X-ray diffraction. H atoms shown on ethylene are disordered about two positions.
elements.clean_text: 4  Crystal structures of acetylene (291 mbar) and ethylene (273 mbar) adsorbed in Cu[Ni(pdt)2], as determined using powder X-ray diffraction. H atoms shown on ethylene are disordered about two positions.

elements.content: The adsorption of ethylene was similarly observed at various pressures (Figures S17–S21 and Table S4), and again excess electron density was observable in the Fourier difference map with respect to the degassed structure. The position of ethylene within the structure was modeled as two carbon atoms with a constrained bond length of 1.34 Å. As shown in b, ethylene appears similarly centered along the square channel axis, 3.4193(2) Å from the centroids of the pyrazine rings, with no observed reduction in symmetry with respect to Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2], and only a very small lattice expansion of 0.3% upon adsorption. Given the similarity in chemical structure, the larger adsorbates analyzed by gas adsorption likely prefer the same adsorption site within the framework, albeit with only about one-half of those sites occupied. The relatively strong binding of acetylene and ethylene, a, is likely attributed to their ideal fit within the pore dimensions of the Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] lattice (Figure S22).

As shown in b, ethylene appears similarly centered along the square channel axis, 3.4193(2) Å from the centroids of the pyrazine rings, with no observed reduction in symmetry with respect to Cu[Ni(pdt)2], and only a very small lattice expansion of 0.3% upon adsorption. Given the similarity in chemical structure, the larger adsorbates analyzed by gas adsorption likely prefer the same adsorption site within the framework, albeit with only about one-half of those sites occupied. The relatively strong binding of acetylene and ethylene, a, is likely attributed to their ideal fit within the pore dimensions of the Cu[Ni(pdt)2] lattice (Figure S22).

elements.content: A series of dosing and evacuation cycles were initially carried out on a pressed pellet of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] with ethylene at pressures ranging from 0.5 to 8 mbar, resulting in transient changes in measured current at constant applied voltage (Figure S9). Significantly, each evacuation resulted in a return to the baseline current, indicating that this adsorbate-induced change in conductivity is reversible. During the dose-evacuation cycling, the conductance saturated after only ∼10 s, a relatively fast response, suggesting that the equilibration time for this change is on a time scale similar to gas adsorption and therefore that the two measurements may be conducted simultaneously. However, given the extremely small amount of material used in the conductivity measurements, the adsorption isotherms shown in a were collected separately using a larger quantity of loose powder from the same synthesis batch obtained by methods established previously. These measurements were then used for all subsequent quantitative analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Modulation of Conductivity upon Gas Adsorption

A series of dosing and evacuation cycles were initially carried out on a pressed pellet of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] with ethylene at pressures ranging from 0.5 to 8 mbar, resulting in transient changes in measured current at constant applied voltage (Figure S9). Significantly, each evacuation resulted in a return to the baseline current, indicating that this adsorbate-induced change in conductivity is reversible. During the dose-evacuation cycling, the conductance saturated after only ~10 s, a relatively fast response, suggesting that the equilibration time for this change is on a time scale similar to gas adsorption and therefore that the two measurements may be conducted simultaneously. However, given the extremely small amount of material used in the conductivity measurements, the adsorption isotherms shown in a were collected separately using a larger quantity of loose powder from the same synthesis batch obtained by methods established previously. These measurements were then used for all subsequent quantitative analysis.

elements.content: Room temperature, steady state conductivities of the phases Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]·nC x H y were determined under constant current conditions as a function of pressure. As shown in b, the change in conductance, Δσ, was normalized to the initial baseline conductance, σ0, which was measured prior to gas dosing at 1 μbar. Equilibration times for both adsorption and conductivity were established using pressure stabilization conditions preset by the gas adsorption analyzer. Figure S10 shows a typical voltage response data collected during the sequential gas dosing and equilibration procedure. The steady-state pressure dependence of the conductivity was fit using an equation identical in form to the Langmuir–Freundlich model used to fit the gas adsorption isotherms. While this model is tentatively empirical, the apparent goodness of fit and the qualitative similarity in curvature to the corresponding gas adsorption isotherms does suggest that conductivity depends linearly upon the quantity of gas adsorbed. We note that while a qualitative Langmuir–Freundlich dependence on analyte concentration has been observed in other chemiresistive sensors, linear and logarithmic concentration dependences are also common.

As shown in b, the change in conductance, Δσ, was normalized to the initial baseline conductance, σ0, which was measured prior to gas dosing at 1 μbar. Equilibration times for both adsorption and conductivity were established using pressure stabilization conditions preset by the gas adsorption analyzer. Figure S10 shows a typical voltage response data collected during the sequential gas dosing and equilibration procedure. The steady-state pressure dependence of the conductivity was fit using an equation identical in form to the Langmuir-Freundlich model used to fit the gas adsorption isotherms. While this model is tentatively empirical, the apparent goodness of fit and the qualitative similarity in curvature to the corresponding gas adsorption isotherms does suggest that conductivity depends linearly upon the quantity of gas adsorbed. We note that while a qualitative Langmuir-Freundlich dependence on analyte concentration has been observed in other chemiresistive sensors, linear and logarithmic concentration dependences are also common.

elements.content: Noting the similarity in shape between the gas adsorption and conductivity isotherms, we now consider the three smallest adsorbates ethane, ethylene, and acetylene. The conductivity and adsorption curves for acetylene-dosed Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] both exhibit a steep rise at very low pressures before turning over to a gradual plateau at ∼0.1 bar. For pressures beyond 0.1 bar, a clear step in conductivity upon subsequent gas dosing was not observed, and therefore quantification of conductance at higher pressures was forgone. However, acetylene did show significant chemiresistivity at the lowest pressures for the adsorbates measured0.5% at 72 μbar. In contrast, conductance data for the ethylene and ethane isotherms could be collected up to 1 bar. Interestingly, for these three adsorbates it is clear that the magnitude of the chemiresistive effect does not depend on either the strength of guest binding or the total adsorption capacity. Indeed, at all pressures significantly more ethylene is adsorbed than ethane, yet the change in conductivity for ethane is greater than that of ethylene for pressures greater than 0.5 bar. This result suggests that differences in the chemical properties of the adsorbatesnot observable by gas adsorption aloneare in part responsible for the modulation in electrical conductivity of the host lattice.

elements.content: The absence of a clear correlation between adsorption capacity and the change in conductivity is better illustrated upon consideration of propylene and propane. Strikingly, the chemiresistive response of propylene- and propane-dosed Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] is nearly double that observed with acetylene and ethylene, despite the lower adsorption capacity and relatively weak adsorbate binding. In the case of the largest adsorbate cis-2-butene, an enhancement in conductivity is observed over that measured with ethane and ethylene, although it is less than that determined for the C3-dosed framework at equivalent pressures. While this difference might be the result of reduced intracrystallite diffusion of cis-2-butene, the similar adsorption profiles of cis-2-butene, propylene, and propane suggest a different origin.

elements.content: To help explain the observed changes in conductivity in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] upon hydrocarbon adsorption, we turned to electronic structure calculations of the desolvated framework and its adsorbate–host complexes with acetylene and ethylene. Importantly, the optimized structures of the adsorbate–host complexes are in good agreement with the structures determined by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S34). A computational study of all possible spin configurations for Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was performed (Figure S23), and indicated that the antiferromagnetic phase is slightly more stable than the ferromagnetic phase (Tables S5–S7). It was further demonstrated that the physisorption of both gases is favorable.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Structure Determinations

To help explain the observed changes in conductivity in Cu[Ni(pdt)2] upon hydrocarbon adsorption, we turned to electronic structure calculations of the desolvated framework and its adsorbate-host complexes with acetylene and ethylene. Importantly, the optimized structures of the adsorbate-host complexes are in good agreement with the structures determined by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S34). A computational study of all possible spin configurations for Cu[Ni(pdt)2] was performed (Figure S23), and indicated that the antiferromagnetic phase is slightly more stable than the ferromagnetic phase (Tables S5-S7). It was further demonstrated that the physisorption of both gases is favorable.

elements.content: The calculations show that the projected density of states (Figure S25) has a nickel dithiolene contribution to the valence band edge and a primarily copper-based conduction band with a theoretical band gap of 2.1 eV, in good agreement with the previously reported optical band gap of ∼2 eV. There are no sizable differences in the electronic structure of bare Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] and the Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]-adsorbate host–guest complexes (Figures S24–S33). As expected, the band structure at the frontier displays little dispersion (<0.3 eV; Figure S24) and is consistent with a charge hopping model for charge transport.
elements.clean_text: The calculations show that the projected density of states (Figure S25) has a nickel dithiolene contribution to the valence band edge and a primarily copper-based conduction band with a theoretical band gap of 2.1 eV, in good agreement with the previously reported optical band gap of ~2 eV. There are no sizable differences in the electronic structure of bare Cu[Ni(pdt)2] and the Cu[Ni(pdt)2]-adsorbate host-guest complexes (Figures S24-S33). As expected, the band structure at the frontier displays little dispersion (<0.3 eV; Figure S24) and is consistent with a charge hopping model for charge transport.

elements.content: A more intuitive understanding of the observed changes in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] conductivity emerged by examining the variation of conductivity as a function of phase composition, rather than absolute pressure. Using the described isotherm fits, points of equivalent pressure in a and b were calculated to determine the conductivity–composition relationships plotted in c. For all gases except cis-2-butene, the conductivity of each hydrocarbon-loaded framework exhibits an approximately linear dependence on the equivalent of gas adsorbed. Here, we define the slope of each plotthe change in conductance per equivalent of gas adsorbedas the sensitivity, S, of conductivity in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] to each adsorbate (Figures S36–S41 and Table S16). The linear regime of each plot was determined using the random sample consensus method (see the Supporting Information for details). From this method, we found that sensitivity increases in the order acetylene ∼ ethylene < ethane < propylene ∼ cis-2-butene < propane. Interestingly, the conductivity is least sensitive to the quantity of acetylene adsorbed (S = 0.153(9)), followed closely by ethylene (S = 0.172(6)), a surprising result given that acetylene interacts most strongly with the host lattice.
elements.clean_text:
Conductivity-Composition Profiles

A more intuitive understanding of the observed changes in Cu[Ni(pdt)2] conductivity emerged by examining the variation of conductivity as a function of phase composition, rather than absolute pressure. Using the described isotherm fits, points of equivalent pressure in a and b were calculated to determine the conductivity-composition relationships plotted in c. For all gases except cis-2-butene, the conductivity of each hydrocarbon-loaded framework exhibits an approximately linear dependence on the equivalent of gas adsorbed. Here, we define the slope of each plotthe change in conductance per equivalent of gas adsorbedas the sensitivity, S, of conductivity in Cu[Ni(pdt)2] to each adsorbate (Figures S36-S41 and Table S16). The linear regime of each plot was determined using the random sample consensus method (see the Supporting Information for details). From this method, we found that sensitivity increases in the order acetylene ~ ethylene < ethane < propylene ~ cis-2-butene < propane. Interestingly, the conductivity is least sensitive to the quantity of acetylene adsorbed (S = 0.153(9)), followed closely by ethylene (S = 0.172(6)), a surprising result given that acetylene interacts most strongly with the host lattice.

elements.content: Excluding cis-2-butene, the most immediately apparent trend is that the sensitivity increases with increasing molecular size (). When a hydrocarbon gas is adsorbed in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2], it collides with the pore walls in a dynamic process that results in new vibrational excited states that are absent in the evacuated phase. Given that a nearest neighbor-type hopping mechanism was attributed to the conductivity in the evacuated framework, the charge hopping process in the guest-occupied material may likewise be described as charge carriers traversing a thermal barrier. Microscopically, the hopping probability for a charge carrier, P, is proportional to the attempt frequency, ν, for a charge hopping a single barrier (). P = υ e − E A / k B Upon gas dosing, the steady-state density of vibrational excitations in the host lattice increases proportionally with the quantity of gas adsorbed. As such, it may be expected that the conductivity scales with the ensemble of states available to exchange heat with the host latticethat is, states available to induce a hopping attempt. The relative number of states added per adsorbate molecule can be quantified empirically as the gas phase specific heat capacity, C p. A plot of the relationship between C p at constant pressure and the sensitivity of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] to each adsorbate is shown in , and the specific values are provided in . Here, acetylene, ethylene, ethane, propylene, and propane show a linear correlation with their reported values of C p at room temperature. We also considered other molecular parameters that increase in magnitude with size (e.g., polarizability and kinetic diameter), but these were found to correlate poorly with the observed trends in sensitivity.

Adsorption capacity, Q ads, is reported in units of moles adsorbate per mole Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]. Heat capacity, C p, (ref ) is reported in units of J/mol·K. Sensitivity, S, is approximated as the slope of the conductivity–composition profiles in Figure c.

Capacity and Δσ/σ0 are reported at 0.1 bar for acetylene and 1 bar for all other gases (Figure b).

As observed for the conductivity isotherms, the chemiresistive effect for Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] in the presence of cis-2-butene is clearly different from the other adsorbates, even when estimating the sensitivity in the low-loading regime. This unique result may originate from the adsorbed molecule exhibiting fewer degrees of freedomeffectively a lower specific heat capacitythan cis-2-butene expresses in the gas phase. The plateau at higher loadings in c is not attributed to a further reduction in heat capacity, but rather is likely competing adsorption of additional cis-2-butene on the crystallite surface, as supported by the gas adsorption isotherm.

elements.content: In the case of ethane, the quantity of adsorbed gas and the change in conductivity were measured as a function of time, enabling a kinetics analysis of the chemiresistive effect to be compared to the equilibration of the bulk gas-powder mixture. An exemplary equilibration curve is shown in for the dosing of ethane from 19 to 45 mbar. The observed rate of adsorption suggests a combination of rate limiting effects: over very short times (less than 1 min), gas adsorption is limited by diffusion and gas conduction through the manifold, while over longer time intervals, the rate of adsorption corresponds best with an equilibration-based kinetics model for the reversible adsorption–desorption process (Figure S42). In contrast to the equilibration of the bulk composition, the cell conductance appears to equilibrate on a shorter time scale. In fact, the saturation kinetics were masked in large part by gas conduction through the manifold in the first few seconds after dosing, an observation supported by the gas conduction-induced echo effect occurring in the first ∼30 s. Over the entire equilibration interval, the conductivity consistently saturated more rapidly than the bulk guest adsorption for all measured steps in pressure.
elements.clean_text:
Kinetics Analysis of Adsorption and Conductance upon Gas Dosing

In the case of ethane, the quantity of adsorbed gas and the change in conductivity were measured as a function of time, enabling a kinetics analysis of the chemiresistive effect to be compared to the equilibration of the bulk gas-powder mixture. An exemplary equilibration curve is shown in  for the dosing of ethane from 19 to 45 mbar. The observed rate of adsorption suggests a combination of rate limiting effects: over very short times (less than 1 min), gas adsorption is limited by diffusion and gas conduction through the manifold, while over longer time intervals, the rate of adsorption corresponds best with an equilibration-based kinetics model for the reversible adsorption-desorption process (Figure S42). In contrast to the equilibration of the bulk composition, the cell conductance appears to equilibrate on a shorter time scale. In fact, the saturation kinetics were masked in large part by gas conduction through the manifold in the first few seconds after dosing, an observation supported by the gas conduction-induced echo effect occurring in the first ~30 s. Over the entire equilibration interval, the conductivity consistently saturated more rapidly than the bulk guest adsorption for all measured steps in pressure.

elements.content: One possible explanation for the different equilibration behavior is that conductivity in the pressed pellet is likely limited by intercrystallite contact resistances, an effect broadly associated with pressed pellet conductivity measurements. Conduction through a single crystal is expected to be much higher than between crystals. As such, a small relative decrease in resistance at the crystallite contacts may cause a disproportionately large change in the resistance of the samples, while a comparable relative decrease in resistance within a single crystal would be largely masked. A similar rationale has been offered to explain the mechanism of chemiresistance in sintered metal–oxide materials, where the conductivity of grain boundaries and interparticle contacts are believed to be most sensitive to gas binding.

Conduction through a single crystal is expected to be much higher than between crystals. As such, a small relative decrease in resistance at the crystallite contacts may cause a disproportionately large change in the resistance of the samples, while a comparable relative decrease in resistance within a single crystal would be largely masked. A similar rationale has been offered to explain the mechanism of chemiresistance in sintered metal-oxide materials, where the conductivity of grain boundaries and interparticle contacts are believed to be most sensitive to gas binding.

elements.content: The foregoing results show the conductivity of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] to be remarkably sensitive to solvation state. In particular, the acetonitrile-solvated material Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]·nCH3CN exhibits a conductivity that is 200 times less than that of the evacuated material. In addition, Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] exhibits impressive adsorption of the gaseous hydrocarbons ethane, ethylene, acetylene, propane, propylene, and cis-2-butene, which motivated our investigation of the charge transport properties of the material upon gas adsorption. It was demonstrated that Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] indeed exhibits significant changes in conductivity dependent on hydrocarbon identity, rendering it an intriguing case study for the development of metal–organic frameworks for use in next-generation chemiresistive sensors. Here, the change in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] conductance was found to be independent of binding strength in the case of all gases tested, and rather, the conductivity increases linearly only with the quantity of gas adsorbed in the framework. Ultimately, the sensitivity of conductance in Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] guest insertion correlates strongly with the gas-phase specific heat capacity of the adsorbate. We note that such a contribution is likely general to all materials that display a physisorption-based chemiresistivity. In the case of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2], the largest adsorbatecis-2-buteneviolates the observed trend with molar heat capacity, consistent with a possible nanoconfinement effect. The conductivity trends were further investigated using electronic structure calculations for the pristine Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] and Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]-adsorbate complexes, and found to be consistent with a hopping based transport model. Finally, initial kinetics analysis of the chemiresistive and adsorption processes indicate grain and interparticle contacts are transport-limiting, and sensor performance may therefore be further optimized through nanostructuring.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The foregoing results show the conductivity of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] to be remarkably sensitive to solvation state. In particular, the acetonitrile-solvated material Cu[Ni(pdt)2]⋅nCH3CN exhibits a conductivity that is 200 times less than that of the evacuated material. In addition, Cu[Ni(pdt)2] exhibits impressive adsorption of the gaseous hydrocarbons ethane, ethylene, acetylene, propane, propylene, and cis-2-butene, which motivated our investigation of the charge transport properties of the material upon gas adsorption. It was demonstrated that Cu[Ni(pdt)2] indeed exhibits significant changes in conductivity dependent on hydrocarbon identity, rendering it an intriguing case study for the development of metal-organic frameworks for use in next-generation chemiresistive sensors. Here, the change in Cu[Ni(pdt)2] conductance was found to be independent of binding strength in the case of all gases tested, and rather, the conductivity increases linearly only with the quantity of gas adsorbed in the framework. Ultimately, the sensitivity of conductance in Cu[Ni(pdt)2] guest insertion correlates strongly with the gas-phase specific heat capacity of the adsorbate. We note that such a contribution is likely general to all materials that display a physisorption-based chemiresistivity. In the case of Cu[Ni(pdt)2], the largest adsorbatecis-2-buteneviolates the observed trend with molar heat capacity, consistent with a possible nanoconfinement effect. The conductivity trends were further investigated using electronic structure calculations for the pristine Cu[Ni(pdt)2] and Cu[Ni(pdt)2]-adsorbate complexes, and found to be consistent with a hopping based transport model. Finally, initial kinetics analysis of the chemiresistive and adsorption processes indicate grain and interparticle contacts are transport-limiting, and sensor performance may therefore be further optimized through nanostructuring.

elements.content: More generally, we present an alternative direction for the development of new chemiresistive sensor materials focused on bulk gas adsorption properties, rather than the high temperature reactivity of surface modified composites. Given the unrivaled gas adsorption and separation properties of metal–organic frameworks at large, this class of materials are poised for implementation in powerful new gas sensor devices. Ongoing work in this area would do well to include a focus on the chemiresistive response of protic and redox-active adsorbates to determine more broadly the factors influencing the relative chemiresistivities in a framework with different adsorbates.

cln_elements.content: The synthesis of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was adapted from a previous report. A flask was charged with 270 mL of acetonitrile and sparged with dry N2 for 30 min. Next, Na2[Ni­(pdt)2] (0.630 g, 1.62 mmol) was added to the solvent and the solution was stirred. A separate flask was charged with 75 mL of acetonitrile, sparged with dry N2 for 30 min, and CuI (0.309 g, 1.62 mmol) was added. While under a positive atmosphere of N2, the CuI solution was slowly added to the solution of Na2[Ni­(pdt)2] via a syringe, which resulted in the rapid precipitation of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] as a black solid. The solid was filtered on 0.22-μm nylon filter paper in air and activated overnight at 90 °C under high vacuum on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument equipped with a turbo pump, yielding 0.453 g (69%) of the product as a dark red microcrystalline solid. The X-ray powder diffraction pattern for the activated material is shown in Figure S1, and the gas adsorption isotherm used to calculate the Langmuir surface area is provided in Figure S2. Elemental Analysis for Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2]: calculated, C 23.63%, H 0.99%, N 13.78%, S 31.54%; found, C 22.92%, H 1.05%, N 13.74%, S 30.43%.

Modified Synthesis of Cu[Ni(pdt)2]

The synthesis of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] was adapted from a previous report. A flask was charged with 270 mL of acetonitrile and sparged with dry N2 for 30 min. Next, Na2[Ni(pdt)2] (0.630 g, 1.62 mmol) was added to the solvent and the solution was stirred. A separate flask was charged with 75 mL of acetonitrile, sparged with dry N2 for 30 min, and CuI (0.309 g, 1.62 mmol) was added. While under a positive atmosphere of N2, the CuI solution was slowly added to the solution of Na2[Ni(pdt)2] via a syringe, which resulted in the rapid precipitation of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] as a black solid. The solid was filtered on 0.22-μm nylon filter paper in air and activated overnight at 90 °C under high vacuum on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument equipped with a turbo pump, yielding 0.453 g (69%) of the product as a dark red microcrystalline solid. The X-ray powder diffraction pattern for the activated material is shown in Figure S1, and the gas adsorption isotherm used to calculate the Langmuir surface area is provided in Figure S2. Elemental Analysis for Cu[Ni(pdt)2]: calculated, C 23.63%, H 0.99%, N 13.78%, S 31.54%; found, C 22.92%, H 1.05%, N 13.74%, S 30.43%.

cln_elements.content: The synthesis of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] was performed via a slight modification of the previously reported procedure to afford a dark red crystalline powder with a nearly identical Langmuir surface area of 426 m2/g. The structure of Cu­[Ni­(pdt)2] () has been previously reported and consists of sulfur-coordinated square planar nickel­(II) pyrazine-2,3-dithiolate units linked by nitrogen-coordinated square planar copper­(II) centers in a three-dimensional lattice. The resulting framework features square channels with edge dimensions defined by the Cu···Cu separation of 6.8132(10) Å and walls that are lined by the [Ni­(pdt)2]2– complexes. While the structure is anisotropic, significant conductivity along any of the three crystallographic axes may be expected, in view of the similarity in metal coordination environments and connectivity.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The synthesis of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] was performed via a slight modification of the previously reported procedure to afford a dark red crystalline powder with a nearly identical Langmuir surface area of 426 m2/g. The structure of Cu[Ni(pdt)2] () has been previously reported and consists of sulfur-coordinated square planar nickel(II) pyrazine-2,3-dithiolate units linked by nitrogen-coordinated square planar copper(II) centers in a three-dimensional lattice. The resulting framework features square channels with edge dimensions defined by the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation of 6.8132(10) Å and walls that are lined by the [Ni(pdt)2]2- complexes. While the structure is anisotropic, significant conductivity along any of the three crystallographic axes may be expected, in view of the similarity in metal coordination environments and connectivity.
